name: hard coal power plant construction, 100MW | hard coal power plant | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/6161/documentation

This dataset represents the components of a 100 MW coal power plant.;[This dataset was already contained in the ecoinvent database version 2. It was not individually updated during the transfer to ecoinvent version 3. Life Cycle Impact Assessment results may still have changed, as they are affected by changes in the supply chain, i.e. in other datasets. This dataset was generated following the ecoinvent quality guidelines for version 2. It may have been subject to central changes described in the ecoinvent version 3 change report (http://www.ecoinvent.org/database/ecoinvent-version-3/reports-of-changes/), and the results of the central updates were reviewed extensively. The changes added e.g. consistent water flows and other information throughout the database. The documentation of this dataset can be found in the ecoinvent reports of version 2, which are still available via the ecoinvent website. The change report linked above covers all central changes that were made during the conversion process.]

From pasture land forseen for the construction of a coal power plant.

This activity ends with a constructed coal power plant, having a total of 150'000 fully load hours. The datasets includes apart the materials necessary for the construction of the hard coal power plant also the construction efforts, land use as well as the disposal of all materials.
category: F:Construction/42:Civil engineering/422:Construction of utility projects/4220:Construction of utility projects

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: German data for the end of the 1980s and US data for early 1980s.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: The 100 MW coal power plant is installed with an electrical filter and a flue gas desulfurization (DeSOx). It represents an average technology in 1980s.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Based on literature data for coal power plants.

exchanges.description:
The materials depend on the capacity, fuel used, applied environmental technology and local conditions. Local conditions in particular, determine the amount of concrete for the foundation and the construction effort for the cooling tower and storage yards.
As medium load power plant the hard coal power plant achieves typically 4'000 fully load hours per year. As a result of warm and cold cycles, 150’000 fully load hours in total are assumed. This corresponds to a lifetime of 33 years. The lifetime is a conservative estimate, since coal power plants may be operated 50 years or more. The fact that coal power plants are modernized several times during their lifetime is not considered. That would cause an additional material consumption. However, increases the lifetime and reduces the material consumption per generated unit of energy.
EcoSpold01Location=GLO

flow.name: hard coal power plant
flow.category: F:Construction/42:Civil engineering/422:Construction of utility projects/4220:Construction of utility projects

Further references:
DOE (1983) Energy Technology Characterizations Handbook; Environmental Pollution and Control Factors. U.S. Department of Energy. Washington, D.C.
Gysel B. (1993) Personal communication, Sulzer Thermtec, 5.2.1993.
ORNL (1980) A Methodology and a Preliminary Data Base for Examining the Health Risks of Electricity Generation from Uranium and Coal Fuels. Oak Ridge, USA.
Fritsche U., Rausch L. Simon K.-H. (1989) Umweltanalyse von Energie-, Transport- und Stoffsystemen: Gesamt-Emissions-Modell Integrierter Systeme (GEMIS) Version 2.0. Darmstadt/Kassel.
Uerpmann E.-P. (1990) Betriebserfahrungen mit nasser Rauchgasentschwefelung in Braunkohlekraftwerken. In: VGB-Seminar Rauchgasreinigung und Reststoffentsorgung in Kraftwerken, Industrie- und Heizkraftwerken. Cottbus, Deutschland.

defaultProvider.category: C:Manufacturing/24:Manufacture of basic metals/242:Manufacture of basic precious and other non-ferrous metals/2420:Manufacture of basic precious and other non-ferrous metals

exchanges.description:
Estimation. General information on land use of coal power plants can be found in (Jensch 1988), (VDI 1993), (Jacobs et al. 1981), (GEK 1978), (OECD 1985), (DOE 1983), (IAEA 1991) and vary from 100-3700 m2/MW. The largest deviations arise from the consideration of landfill sites for ash and residues from flue gas cleaning. In the U.S., these are deposited on the plant site. In Europe, the values vary from 100-600 m2/MW. Important influencing factors are the size of the coal storage, capacity of the plant, applied method of cooling , use of environmental technology, area available and the chosen boundary. These values are also confirmed by exemplary values for environmental statements (HKW Heilbronn 2002), (RDK 2000). 30m2 per MW are assumed for storage area, 60m2 per MW for building area and 80m2 per MW for traffic area, whereby traffic area is assumed for the tanks of the power plant (CORINE 121a). The area is derived from 4’000 fully load hours per year resp. 150’000 fully load hours in total.

Further references:
VDI (1993) Instrumente zur Minderung energiebedingter Klimagasemissionen IKARUS. VDI Bericht 1043. Tagung Schliersee, 29./30. Apri 1993, Schliersee, Deutschland.
DOE (1983) Energy Technology Characterizations Handbook; Environmental Pollution and Control Factors. U.S. Department of Energy. Washington, D.C.
Jacobs H., Kreutzer A., Pleyer H., Stoll A. (1981) Grundflächenbedarf von Kraftwerken. In: Siemens-Energietechnik 3 Heft 8-9, s. 298-302.
GEK (1978) Die Umweltbelastung im Energiebereich. Schriftenreihe der Eidg. Kommission für die Gesamtenergiekonzeption, Studie Nr. 24, Bern.
OECD (1985) Environmental Effects of Electricity Generation. Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development/International Energy Agency, Paris.
IAEA (1991) Senior Expert Symposium on the electricity and the environment. Helsinki 13-17 May 1991, Vienna.
RDK (2000) Rheinhafen-Dampfkraftwerk Karlsruhe. Umwelterklärung 2000. Energie Baden-Württemberg AG, Karlsruhe.

Further references:
DOE (1983) Energy Technology Characterizations Handbook; Environmental Pollution and Control Factors. U.S. Department of Energy. Washington, D.C.
Gysel B. (1993) Personal communication, Sulzer Thermtec, 5.2.1993.
ORNL (1980) A Methodology and a Preliminary Data Base for Examining the Health Risks of Electricity Generation from Uranium and Coal Fuels. Oak Ridge, USA.
Fritsche U., Rausch L. Simon K.-H. (1989) Umweltanalyse von Energie-, Transport- und Stoffsystemen: Gesamt-Emissions-Modell Integrierter Systeme (GEMIS) Version 2.0. Darmstadt/Kassel.

exchanges.description:
Estimation. General information on land use of coal power plants can be found in (Jensch 1988), (VDI 1993), (Jacobs et al. 1981), (GEK 1978), (OECD 1985), (DOE 1983), (IAEA 1991) and vary from 100-3700 m2/MW. The largest deviations arise from the consideration of landfill sites for ash and residues from flue gas cleaning. In the U.S., these are deposited on the plant site. In Europe, the values vary from 100-600 m2/MW. Important influencing factors are the size of the coal storage, capacity of the plant, applied method of cooling , use of environmental technology, area available and the chosen boundary. These values are also confirmed by exemplary values for environmental statements (HKW Heilbronn 2002), (RDK 2000). 30m2 per MW are assumed for storage area, 60m2 per MW for building area and 80m2 per MW for traffic area, whereby traffic area is assumed for the tanks of the power plant (CORINE 121a). The area is derived from 4’000 fully load hours per year resp. 150’000 fully load hours in total.

Further references:
VDI (1993) Instrumente zur Minderung energiebedingter Klimagasemissionen IKARUS. VDI Bericht 1043. Tagung Schliersee, 29./30. Apri 1993, Schliersee, Deutschland.
DOE (1983) Energy Technology Characterizations Handbook; Environmental Pollution and Control Factors. U.S. Department of Energy. Washington, D.C.
Jacobs H., Kreutzer A., Pleyer H., Stoll A. (1981) Grundflächenbedarf von Kraftwerken. In: Siemens-Energietechnik 3 Heft 8-9, s. 298-302.
GEK (1978) Die Umweltbelastung im Energiebereich. Schriftenreihe der Eidg. Kommission für die Gesamtenergiekonzeption, Studie Nr. 24, Bern.
OECD (1985) Environmental Effects of Electricity Generation. Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development/International Energy Agency, Paris.
IAEA (1991) Senior Expert Symposium on the electricity and the environment. Helsinki 13-17 May 1991, Vienna.
RDK (2000) Rheinhafen-Dampfkraftwerk Karlsruhe. Umwelterklärung 2000. Energie Baden-Württemberg AG, Karlsruhe.
